channel.title: Morning Education
channel.description: Delivered every Monday by 10 a.m., Weekly Education examines the latest news in education politics and policy.

item.title: Defaulted borrowers catch a break — for now
item.description: Student loan borrowers who were about to have their wages and tax refunds seized for lack of payment are getting a reprieve. How long that reprieve will last is an open question.
item.dc:creator: By Rebecca Carballo

item.title: Why Colorado's governor says Democrats should embrace the GOP’s ‘free money’
item.description: Republicans muscled a federal tax credit into law last year to help pay for private school and other education expenses. At least one Democratic governor thinks his party colleagues should take the money.
item.dc:creator: By Juan Perez Jr.

item.title: Trump’s campus crackdown heads for the policy books
item.description: President Donald Trump’s unprecedented pressure campaign against colleges and school districts in 2025 is shifting into the rulemaking phase in the new year.
item.dc:creator: By Bianca Quilantan

item.title: The inside view of McMahon’s plans for special education
item.description: Disability advocates alarmed by the Trump administration’s plans for special education say a recent meeting with Education Secretary Linda McMahon did not alleviate what one participant described as “grave concern.”
item.dc:creator: By Juan Perez Jr.

item.title: Colleges beg for reprieve from Trump data demand
item.description: The Trump administration is asking colleges to turn over data it believes could reveal whether universities are discriminating against applicants based on race.
item.dc:creator: By Rebecca Carballo and Bianca Quilantan
item.dc:contributor: By Rebecca Carballo and Bianca Quilantan

item.title: The record potential for college aid applications
item.description: High school seniors for the class of 2026 are getting a jump start on applying for cash for college.
item.dc:creator: By Bianca Quilantan

item.title: Why Americans say college isn’t worth the cost
item.description: Broad majorities of Americans say college simply costs too much and doesn’t provide enough benefits to be worth the effort — regardless of their political affiliation, age, and ethnicity.
item.dc:creator: By Juan Perez Jr.
